choices.text: Head ache that worsen on standing

questions.text: All of the following are clinical features of raised intracranial pressure except?
questions.solution:
Symptoms of raised ICP include:

  • High pressure headache - worse on coughing or bending forward.
  • Blurred vision or double vision.
  • Cranial nerve palsies.
  • Fundoscopy can detect papilledema. But this takes time to develop and so may be absent in the acute phase.

Low pressure headaches, encountered after excessive cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) drainage, are typically worse on standing.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 703.

choices.text: It results from dorsal midbrain compression
Sunsetting sign if feature of Parinaud's syndrome

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding Parinaud's syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Parinaud's syndrome -

  • Results from dorsal midbrain compression.
  • Most commonly caused due to a pineal gland tumor.
  • Loss of up-gaze. Downward gaze is usually preserved.
  • Sun setting sign - downward ocular deviation.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 702.

questions.text: CSF produced at rate of?
questions.solution:
• CSF is produced by the choroid plexus and is reabsorbed into the arachnoid villi along the superior sagittal sinus
  • Production from the walls of the ventricles and the choroid plexus is about 20 mL per hour.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 703

choices.text: CSF flows from third ventricle to lateral ventricles
CSF flows from third ventricle to fourth ventricle through foramen of monro
CSF is reabsorbed into arachnoid villi
CSF exits to subarachnoid space via midline foramina of Luschka

questions.text: Identify correct statements for CSF pathway
questions.solution:
• CSF is reabsorbed into the arachnoid villi along the superior sagittal sinus.
  • CSF flows from the lateral ventricles through the foramen of Monro to the third ventricle, then down the cerebral aqueduct to the fourth ventricle, where it exits to the subarachnoid space via the midline foramen of Magendie and the lateral foramina of Luschka.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 703

questions.text: All of the following are causes of communicating hydrocephalus except
questions.solution: Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 703

questions.text: All of the following are included in triad of Normal pressure hydrocephalus except?
questions.solution:
• Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus typically presents with the triad of
    • Gait disturbance,
    • Urinary incontinence and
    • Cognitive decline.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 704.

choices.text: MRI is first line of investigation
In communicating hydrocephalus, LP can confirm raised CSF pressure
Pseudotumor cerebri results in symptomatic raised CSF pressure without ventricular enlargement
NPH is potential reversible cause of dementia

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding hydrocephalus except
questions.solution:
CT is the first line of investigation for hydrocephalus.

Option B - In communicating hydrocephalus, lumbar puncture can confirm the raised CSF pressure and also relieve it temporarily.

Option C - Idiopathic intracranial hypertension or pseudotumor cerebri results in symptomatic raised CSF pressure without ventricular enlargement. CSF diversion may be necessary to prevent permanent visual loss.

Option D - NPH is a potentially reversible cause of dementia.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 704.

choices.text: A shunt valve opening pressure may be high, medium or low
Anti-siphon system incorporated to prevent excessive drainage
High pressure valves can overdrain CSF
Programmable valves offer variable opening pressure.

questions.text: All of the following are correct regarding Ventriculoperitoneal shunt except?
questions.solution:
High pressure valves may fail to allow adequate CSF drainage, whereas low pressure valves can overdrain CSF.

Ventriculoperitoneal shunting -

  • Ventricular catheter inserted into the frontal or occipital horn of the lateral ventricle, while a distal catheter is tunnelled subcutaneously to the abdomen.
  • Ventriculoatrial and ventriculopleural shunting is also possible.
  • A shunt valve, with an opening pressure that may be high, medium or low, is inserted at the junction of these catheters.
  • An anti-siphon system may be incorporated to prevent excessive drainage in the standing position.
  • Programmable valves offer variable opening pressures, adjusted magnetically using a device applied externally over the valve.
  • The valve system will also typically incorporate a CSF reservoir, which allows for percutaneous sampling.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 705.

choices.text: Staff movement in and out of the theatre

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for infection of shunt except?
questions.solution:
75% of shunt infections present within 1 month, reflecting introduction at the time of insertion.

Risk factors include -

  • Very young patients
  • Open myelomeningocoele
  • Long operation time
  • Staff movement in and out of theatre

Treatment -

  • Removal of shunt
  • Antibiotic therapy
  • Shunt reinserted at a new site after infection resolves.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 705-706

questions.text: All of the following are shunt complications except?
questions.solution:
Complications of shunt include -

  • Overdrainage can result in low-pressure headaches, which are typically worse on standing. Collapse of the ventricles can cause accumulation of fluid or blood in the subdural space, resulting in subdural hygroma or subdural haematoma.
  • The slit ventricle syndrome occurs in children treated with shunts, whose ventricles and subarachnoid spaces are underdeveloped, resulting in poor brain compliance. In these patients normal fluctuations in ICP are exaggerated so that coughing and straining may cause symptoms of raised ICP.
  • Shunts are vulnerable to disconnection, infection and blockage.
  • Any shunt blockage may not be evident on scan, as the ventricles fail to enlarge.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 705-706

questions.text: Endoscopic third ventriculostomy can be use in treatment of which type of hydrocephalus?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic Third Ventriculostomy (ETV) -

This procedure is useful in obstructive (non-communicating) hydrocephalus due to aqueduct stenosis.

A neuroendoscope is inserted into the frontal horn of the lateral ventricle and then into the third ventricle via the foramen of Monro.

The floor of the ventricle is then opened between the mammillary bodies and the pituitary recess.

Free drainage between the third ventricle and the adjacent subarachnoid cisterns is then possible, without the infection risk posed by implanted tubing.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 706.

choices.text: Raised ICP should be excluded before LP
CSF should be sent for microscopy and culture
Treatment is broad spectrum antibiotics including anaerobic coverage

questions.text: All of the following are correct regarding meningitis except
questions.solution:
• Meningitis is a feared complication of neurosurgery and head injury.
  • CT scan allows exclusion of raised intracranial pressure and should be done prior to lumbar puncture.
  • CSF should be sent for microscopy and culture, along with protein and glucose level assay.
  • Treatment is with broad spectrum antibiotics including anaerobic coverage.
  • Empirical therapy is started with 3rd generation cephalosporin + Vancomycin ± Ampicillin.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 706

questions.text: Identify organism causing brain abscess due to food contamination
questions.solution: Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 707

choices.text: Typical presenting features include low grade fever, confusion, seizure and focal deficit
CT scan without contrast is initial imaging modality of choice
Hypodense oedematous brain represents early cerebritis
The classic appearances is smooth walled, well defined, ring enhancing mass

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding brain abscess except
questions.solution:
CT scan with contrast is the initial imaging modality of choice for brain abscess. It shows a classic appearance of a smooth-walled, well-defined, ring enhancing mass.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 706.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
• Axial computed tomography scan with contrast of a patient with frontal sinusitis presenting with seizures. Early cerebritis is evident in the left frontal region (arrow).
  • Axial computed tomography scan with contrast of the same patient as weeks later. A ring-enhancing smooth-walled lesion is evident, an abscess suitable for image guided drainage.

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Page Number-707.

choices.text: Craniotomy or craniectomy and drainage of collection

questions.text: Treatment of choice for subdural empyema
questions.solution:
Subdural empyema refers to an infective collection in the subdural space. This may develop as a result of sinusitis, mastoiditis or meningitis, and can complicate trauma or surgery.

In empyema, pus will generally collect in the parafalcine region and over the convexity, triggering inflammation and thrombosis in the cortical veins, which helps to explain the high mortality rate.

Craniotomy or craniectomy allows drainage of the collection and relieves raised ICP and is the treatment of choice.

Burrhole drainage, and occasionally IV antibiotics without surgical intervention, may also be considered.

Lumbar puncture should not be performed given the risk of herniation.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 708

choices.text: It represents hematogenous spread from primary pulmonary foci
TB meningitis commonly affects young children
Tuberculoma is discrete tumour like granuloma at base of the cerebral hemispheres
Tuberculous abscess is predominantly in immune competent host

questions.text: All of the following are correct regarding tuberculous infection of CNS except
questions.solution:
• Tuberculosis (TB) infection of the central nervous system (CNS) represents haematogenous spread from primary pulmonary foci.
  • A high index of suspicion is required, especially when population or individual risk factors are present.
  • TB can result in a diverse but overlapping spectrum of pathology, including in the head:
    • Tuberculous meningitis - this commonly affects young children; CT demonstrates intense meningeal enhancement, and hydrocephalus is a common sequela;
    • Tuberculoma - discrete tumour-like granulomas at the base of the cerebral hemispheres, presenting with mass effect;
    • Tuberculous abscess - seen predominantly in immunocompromised hosts, this represents progression of a tuberculoma with prominent central caseating necrosis;
    • Miliary tuberculosis - describes a diffuse distribution of multiple small tuberculomas through brain substance.
    • Where the meninges are involved, lymphocytes can be expected to predominate in the CSF, rather than the polymorphs seen with other bacterial meningitides.
    • The increase in protein content and reduction in glucose concentration are also less marked.
    • Ziehl-Nielsen staining for mycobacteria is frequently negative, and polymerase chain reaction testing offers relatively rapid diagnosis compared to culture for acid-fast bacilli which may take weeks.
    • A 20-30 mL CSF sample allows spinning to increase the culture yield.
    • Management is with anti-tuberculous therapy; hydrocephalus may require shunt insertion.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 708

questions.text: Most common cause of spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Spontaneous subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) is usually the result of -

  • Bleeding from a ruptured aneurysm (~80% of SAH)
  • Arteriovenous malformation (AVM)

Most ruptured aneurysms are located in the circle of Willis, at branch points in the arterial tree associated with turbulent blood flow.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 708-709.

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for aneurysmal bleeding except?
questions.solution:
• Aneurysmal bleeding has an incidence of 10 - 15 per 100 000 population per year. Risk factors include
    • age,
    • female sex,
    • hypertension,
    • smoking,
    • cocaine abuse and
    • A family history with two first-degree relatives affected.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 709

questions.text: All of the following genetic disorders predispose to aneurysmal bleeding except?
questions.solution:
Genetic disorders predisposing to aneurysmal bleeding include -

  • Adult Polycystic Kidney Disease
  • Fibromuscular Dysplasia
  • Neurofibromatosis Type 1
  • Ehler -Danlos
  • Marfan's Syndrome

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 709.

questions.text: All of the following are clinical feature of Subarachnoid hemorrhage except?
questions.solution:
Clinical features of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) include -

  • Thunderclap headache - sudden onset and severe
  • Rapid onset vomiting
  • Unresponsiveness
  • Seizures

Diagnosis -

  • CT scan is the investigation of choice. When performed within 12 hours, will confirm bleeding in 98% of cases. The sensitivity of a CT scan deteriorates to less than 50% at 1 week after a bleed.
  • Lumbar puncture should be performed if CT does not confirm SAH but the clinical suspicion is high. LP shows xanthochromic CSF.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 709

questions.text: 60 year old patient brought to emergency room after patient developed sudden onset of headache. On examination patient's GCS is 11/15 and patient has focal neurological deficit. What is WFNS grade of this patient?
questions.solution:
The World Federation of Neurological Surgeons (WFNS) grading of SAH is measured against the condition of the patient after resuscitation rather than at the time of ictus.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 709

questions.text: What is Terson's syndrome?
questions.solution:
The combination of subarachnoid hemorrhage and vitreous haemorrhage (subhyaloid) is known as Terson’s Syndrome.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 709.

choices.text: All patient requires LP for diagnosis of SAH
CSF supernatant should be analysed by spectrophotometry
Sensitivity of CT increase with time to diagnose SAH

questions.text: All statements are incorrect regarding aneurysmal bleeding investigation except?
questions.solution:
• In light of this, patients with a suggestive history and negative CT scan will require LP, especially where presentation is delayed. The CSF supernatant should be analysed by spectrophotometry (visual inspection is not reliable) for the spectra of haemoglobin breakdown products oxyhaemoglobin and bilirubin.
  • These are clearly detectable in samples taken at least 6 and preferably 12 hours after SAH, but not in CSF mixed with fresh blood due to traumatic puncture, and analysed immediately. Failure to exclude SAH with an appropriate delayed LP may necessitate formal cerebral angiography, and the risks this entails.
  • Catheter angiography generally involves access to both vertebral and carotid arteries through the femoral artery under local anaesthetic. This allows visualisation of the vascular anatomy by injection of contrast medium with simultaneous screening.
  • The serious potential risks include ischaemic stroke or arterial dissection (1-2%), and renal failure or allergic reactions attributable to contrast.

Option A: CT scan is the imaging of first choice, and, when performed within 12 hours of ictus, will confirm bleeding in more than 98% of cases. This makes a diagnostic LP unnecessary

Option C: The sensitivity of a CT scan, however, deteriorates to less than 50% at 1 week after a bleed.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 710

questions.text: Gold standard investigation for cerebral aneurysm?
questions.solution:
• CT angiography has a high sensitivity for aneurysms and AVMs, but digital subtraction angiography remains the gold standard.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 710.

questions.text: 'Puff of smoke' appearance on angiography seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
• Moya moya disease describes the progressive obliteration of one or both internal carotid arteries, thought to represent an autoimmune process.
  • The development of external carotid circulation collaterals produces the angiographic 'puff of smoke' appearance responsible for this Japanese-derived name. It presents in youth or early middle age with ischaemia or haemorrhage.
  • Untreated, the majority of patients suffer major deficit or die within 2 years.
  • Ischaemia may be addressed by a variety of bypass techniques, for example by anastomosing the superficial temporal artery (arising from the external carotid) to the middle cerebral artery.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 712

choices.text: Presentation with headache, focal deficits and sign of raised ICP
Clot evacuation should be done to reverse deficit
High blood pressure should be reduced with care

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding ICH except?
questions.solution: Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 711

choices.text: Requires surgery if they cause progressive deficits, intractable epilepsy or recurrent bleeding

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding cavernoma except?
questions.solution:
Cavernoma-

  • Venous anomaly
  • Diagnosed by MRI but not with angiography.
  • Require operation if they cause progressive deficits, intractable epilepsy or recurrent bleeding.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 712

questions.text: Foster-Kennedy syndrome associated with which kind of tumor?
questions.solution:
Foster Kennedy syndrome is associated with olfactory groove meningioma. It presents with -

  • Anosmia
  • Ipsilateral optic atrophy
  • Contralateral papilledema

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 714.

choices.text: All are features of brain tumor

questions.text: All of the following features are associated with brain tumors except?
questions.solution: Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 714.

questions.text: Commonest glial tumors is?
questions.solution:
• Low-grade gliomas (WHO grade II) have a peak incidence in the fourth decade of life, and commonly present with seizures initially.
  • Where tumours encroach on eloquent cortex, especially the speech areas of the dominant hemisphere, awake craniotomy allows mapping of function with surface electrodes at operation, to limit resection and minimise postoperative deficit.
  • High-grade gliomas include anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO grade III) and glioblastoma (WHO grade IV), the commonest glial tumour.
  • They typically present de novo with peak incidence in the fifth and sixth decades of life, respectively, or they may represent transformation of previously diagnosed, or clinically silent, low-grade gliomas. Active treatment consists of maximal resection, high-dose focused radiation therapy, and chemotherapy administered locally as carmustine wafers at the time of resection and/or systemically with oral temozolomide.
  • Median survival for glioblastoma remains just over 12 months.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 715.

questions.text: Most common brain tumour is?
questions.solution:
• Cerebral metastases are the most common brain tumours, and affect about one quarter of cancer sufferers, a proportion that is increasing with extended survival associated with more effective treatment of primary cancers.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 714

questions.text: Which suture is involved in brachycephaly?
questions.solution: Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 719.

questions.text: Most common organ of origin for brain metastasis?
questions.solution: Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 715

questions.text: What is the most common primary malignant tumor in adults?
questions.solution:
• The most common primary malignant tumor in adults is Glioblastoma.
  • The most common primary malignant tumor in children is Medulloblastoma.
  • The most common primary CNS tumor in adults is Astrocytoma.
  • The most common primary CNS tumor in children is Pilocytic astrocytoma.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 48, Cranial neurosurgery, Pg: 715
